metadata.name: Fischbach #199
metadata.description:
#fxhashturnsone

The first 365 crazy days of fxhash - time to celebrate this and take a look back.

The entropy of memories in a vivid photo collage that gives me goosebumps while others might just see moving eye candy. Perspective and perception can be so different.

Based on some of my photos from the last 365 days that trigger emotional memories, even if they are not directly connected. By the way, Fischbach is the name of the small village where I grew up. It was a great time!

How does it work?

Each piece uses pairs of photos and colors (top/bottom).

The animated collage itself is based on two layers. The first layer uses a double buffer to cut, colorize and animate the photos. The second layer is mainly just for screen rendering, debugging and behind-the-scene looks.

Cutting and pasting photos is based on a variable moving color grid, the fixed horizon, the variable position of the photos top/bottom, the previous buffer and some magic distance calculations between them.

The grid itself is a combination of vertical color stripes with variable position and distance factors that determine the color gradient between the two colors, and folds that alternate between the two colors depending on the horizontal and vertical values.

Especially the entropy of the photos and the colored grid influence the pixel movement.

Animation changes are triggered after a random number of frames and effect folds, stripes and photo position. These replace parts of the current collage (fade to black) or add some (discard fragment updates).

Features:

- top color [12] - hue, colorful & bright
- bottom color [6] - hue, less colorful & bright
- top photo [16] (zingst, birds, xmas, zustand, zebra, moving-blocks-mono, fischbach, santanyi, goldblume, ♠4, driften, brand-pyramide, zäpfle, bc, tisa, lieblingspulli)
- bottom photo: [16] (zingst, birds, xmas, zustand, zebra, moving-blocks-mono, fischbach, santanyi, goldblume, ♠4, driften, brand-pyramide, zäpfle, bc, tisa, lieblingspulli)
- horizon [0.618, 0.5, 0.382] (down, center, up)
- hectic [3, 5, 11] (calm, slightly, very)
- horizontal folds [113, 365, 997, 2153, 3987] - used for first animation iteration, variable
- vertical folds [7, 37, 127, 571, 1501, 3147] - used for first animation iteration, variable
- min stripes [1, 3, 5] - used for first animation iteration, variable

Animation and feature selection are based on the deterministic prng Xoshiro128 seeded with the fxhash. This allows repeated playback in the same sequence. The animation is synchronized with frames and not with time.

The preview images are taken after 300 frames.

Shortcuts & interactions:

- spacebar, mouse click or tap touch to trigger animation changes
- `c` to take a picture
- `f` for full screen mode
- `p` to pause
- `h` to see all options

Available query string parameters:

- autopause - enable automatic pausing
- pixelratio=2 - sets the pixel ratio (default: device)
- showannouncement - activates the announcement
- kioskspeed=10 - activates the kiosk mode and sets the speed in seconds
- showinfo - activates the info box

metadata.name: Paper Noise #26
metadata.description:
This series is about finding the beauty in discarded things. It's about seeing the potential for art in the most unexpected places and creating something new from what already exists.

One thing we love about art is that it can be a direct expression of our thoughts and feelings. But what about the happy accidents that can happen when we let go and allow the materials to guide us?

I love the serendipitous moments that arise when I relinquish control, letting the materials show me the way. The printmaking process can be messy and unpredictable. I often use sheets of notebook paper to keep my workspace clean. When I’m done, I save some of the scrap sheets of paper. 

The mark of a dirty brayer, drips of paint, a coffee stain, or a ripped edge can all be embraced as part of the final composition. A similar process happens in generative art, where projects can have near limitless possibilities.

Sheets of paper can represent many things: a blank slate, an adventure, or even noise. This project is dedicated to all the leftovers and forgotten things in the world. It's a reminder that even the smallest piece of paper can be beautiful.

metadata.name: The Emoji Finder Game 🔎 #129
metadata.description:
This is a 'Where's Waldo'-like video game(!) that procedurally generates one of seven fun and hectic "biomes" to search through. Find the specified emoji before time runs out to win! 

The seven biomes are: Safari, Ocean, Space, Kitchen, Twitter, Forest, and City. Share your game links with friends! 

Created by Michael Perusse | https://twitter.com/mrperusse

Created by Michael Perusse | https://twitter.com/mrperusse

metadata.name: linear segmentarity #9
metadata.description:
“We are segmented from all around and in every direction. The human being is a segmentary animal. Segmentarity is inherent to all the strata composing us. Dwelling, getting around, working, playing: life is spatially and socially segmented. The house is segmented according to its rooms’ assigned purposes; streets, according to the order of the city; the factory, according to the nature of the work and operations performed in it. We are segmented in a binary fashion, following the great major dualist oppositions: social classes, but also men-women, adult-children, and so on.” 

-a thousand plateaus: capitalism and schizophrenia, Deleuze and Guattari

Linear Segmentarity explores the concept of a segmented existence, which refers to how our lives are broken up into discreet parts or segments.

I was inspired by the philosophers Deleuze and Guattari. These thinkers studied the ways we are segmented into work and play, family and friends, and past and present. We move through our days in a series of linear segments, each one leading to the next. 

Each segment has its territory with its own rules and way of doing things. We are constantly shifting from one to the next, and the sum of these segments defines our existence. 

Art can help us visualize this hidden aspect of ourselves and feel its impact. Using Javascript to describe the sporadic nature of the world, this project invites us to see the linear segmentarity at work in our environment.

metadata.name: glory hole$ #563
metadata.description:
our consciousness as humans can be distilled into a crudely fashioned hole at an abandoned dave & busters and the meditative state that is endured while sitting on a neglected toilet praying for the sound of disrupted waters. glory holes embody anonymity and pleasure for pleasure's sake. they are creations that cannot be destroyed, as they exist in the memories of anyone who uses or witnesses. many speculate that the carving of the hole is the purest form of human ingenuity and the desire to explore the unknown. formerly limited to the physical space. these glory holes transcend space and time. and exist in that same unknown that tempts us all. legalize ground beef. create nothing. consume everything.

HUGE thank you to @PureSpider for the layered PNG template, this dream would not have been realized without you friend.

metadata.name: unTie #17
metadata.description:
“unTie” is a work for VolumeDAO x fxhash Curated Series “Ties”

Description:
I'm sure many of you, like me, are not people who actively put their true feelings out there. This may be what is often referred to as introversion and shyness. However, our inner world is often very full of emotions. We have that one switch or lock on the door of our heart that is usually closed. It's used to protect ourselves, or to hide ourselves. But, we also need that one moment to let the budding emotions inside us blossom. Yes, maybe it's now! It's time to untie that knot that's been tied for a long time, let the cheer be released, let's cheers, and let's celebrate!

Press [s] to save the image.

By Samuel YAN
Made with p5.js / glsl
